eiâ„¢
In math, the lowercase "ein" symbol (âˆˆ) means "is an element of" or "belongs to" and refers to set membership, while the uppercase letter "E" can refer to the constant e (approximately 2.718), a fundamental mathematical constant, or it can represent the exponent in scientific notation, as in "1.23E+10".  Set membership symbol (âˆˆ)  Symbol: âˆˆ Meaning: "is an element of" or "belongs to". Usage: It's used to show that a particular item is a member of a given set. Example: If 'x' is an element of set 'A', you would write this as x âˆˆ A. The constant e (e) Symbol: A lowercase 'e'.  Meaning: A mathematical constant, also known as Euler's number, with a value of approximately 2.718.  Usage: It's a fundamental constant that appears in many areas of mathematics, science, and economics, similar to pi (Ï€).  Exponent in scientific notation (E) Symbol: An uppercase "E".  Meaning: Stands for "exponent" and is used to multiply the preceding number by 10 to the power of the following number.  Usage: When writing very large or very small numbers on calculators or in computer displays, the "E" notation saves space.  Example: 1.23E+10 means 1.23 multiplied by 10 to the 10th power [1.23 x 10Â¹â°].

0 The placeholder for nothing, which means it doesn't exist. But if it represents nothing then it is something, meaning it exists. How do you divide the something of nothing with the nothing of something? The answer: you can't, if the thing itself is quantum.

You know, I've just finished binge watching all of the AvM and AvA series, and I think I've developed my own theory:  Orange/TSC can basically interact/control most animation based stuffs. With his ability to bring drawings to life, be a pretty good fighter, and is super creative, his skills already make him stupid powerful. Sooooooooo, if he could go super saiyan mode at will, he'd truly be the most overpowered stickfigure in this universe. Hence why it takes very specific circumstances for him to tap into his "God Mode." With this, the most powerful stickman's powers are kept fairly tame so as not to break the universe (which it seems he can do without super god mode powers anyways sooooooo.)  Also, because this debate exists: Orange = Regular stick dude, totally normal, pretty good at beating stick-people up and bringing animation to life. This is normal. Did you know there's an useful method to find the Square Root of Three? (1.732050807568877293527446341505872366â€¦) If 1Â² = 1, 2Â² = 4, and 4 > 3, that square root is between 1 and 2. Find every single number from 1.1 to 1.9 squared. It is between 1.7 and 1.8. Find every single number from 1.71 to 1.79 squared. It is between 1.73 and 1.74. Find every single number from 1.731 to 1.739 squared. It is between 1.732 and 1.733. Repeat this process until the number of digits you want. Works with every root! You see this process is endless, so the Square Root of Three is irrational. Thanks!

Amei o vÃ­deo
A triangle is a fundamental geometric figure defined as a three-sided polygon composed of three straight line segments that connect three non-collinear points, known as vertices. Each triangle has exactly three internal angles, the sum of which is always 180Â°, a fact proven by the Triangle Sum Theorem.  Triangles can be classified by both their sides and angles. Based on sides, they are scalene (no sides equal), isosceles (two sides equal), or equilateral (all sides equal). Based on angles, they are acute (all angles < 90Â°), right (one angle = 90Â°), or obtuse (one angle > 90Â°).  The Pythagorean Theorem applies only to right triangles, stating that aÂ² + bÂ² = cÂ², where c is the hypotenuse. This theorem is a critical principle for calculating the length of sides in a right triangle.  The Triangle Inequality Theorem states that the sum of the lengths of any two sides of a triangle must be greater than the length of the third side. This property ensures that a triangle can exist with the given side lengths.  The Law of Sines and Law of Cosines relate the sides and angles of triangles, which is critical in solving triangles when the necessary information isn't directly available. These laws are key tools in trigonometry and are often used to solve problems in navigation, physics, and engineering.  In a triangle, several key points of intersection define its properties. The centroid is the intersection of the medians, the incenter is where angle bisectors meet and is the center of the incircle, and the circumcenter is where perpendicular bisectors meet and is the center of the circumcircle. The orthocenter is the intersection of altitudes.  Triangles tessellate space, form the basis of trusses, and appear in nature and architecture due to their inherent structural stability. The triangleâ€™s simplicity combined with its strong geometrical properties makes it a cornerstone of both theoretical and applied mathematics.

â¤â¤â¤â¤â¤â¤â¤â¤â¤â¤â¤â¤â¤â¤â¤
THE MATH LORE  0:07 The simplest way to start -- 1 is given axiomatically as the first natural number (though in some Analysis texts, they state first that 0 is a natural number) 0:13 Equality -- First relationship between two objects you learn in a math class. 0:19 Addition -- First of the four fundamental arithmetic operations. 0:27 Repeated addition of 1s, which is how we define the rest of the naturals in set theory; also a foreshadowing for multiplication. 0:49 Addition with numbers other than 1, which can be defined using what we know with adding 1s. (proof omitted) 1:23 Subtraction -- Second of the four arithmetic operations. 1:34 Our first negative number! Which can also be expressed as e^(i*pi), a result of extending the domain of the Taylor series for e^x (\sum x^n/n!) to the complex numbers. 1:49 e^(i*pi) multiplying itself by i, which opens a door to the... imaginary realm? Also alludes to the fact that Orange is actually in the real realm. How can TSC get to the quantity again now?  2:12 Repeated subtraction of 1s, similar to what was done with the naturals. 2:16 Negative times a negative gives positive. 2:24 Multiplication, and an interpretation of it by repeated addition or any operation. 2:27 Commutative property of multiplication, and the factors of 12. 2:35 Division, the final arithmetic operation; also very nice to show that - and / are as related to each other as + and x! 2:37 Division as counting the number of repeated subtractions to zero. 2:49 Division by zero and why it doesn't make sense. Surprised that TSC didn't create a black hole out of that.  3:04 Exponentiation as repeated multiplication. 3:15 How higher exponents corresponds to geometric dimension. 3:29 Anything non-zero to the zeroth power is 1. 3:31 Negative exponents! And how it relates to fractions and division. 3:37 Fractional exponents and square roots! We're getting closer now... 3:43 Decimal expansion of irrational numbers (like sqrt(2)) is irregular. (I avoid saying "infinite" since technically every real number has an infinite decimal expansion...) 3:49 sqrt(-1) gives the imaginary number i, which is first defined by the property i^2 = -1. 3:57 Adding and multiplying complex numbers works according to what we know. 4:00 i^3 is -i, which of course gives us i*e^(i*pi)!  4:14 Refer to 3:49 4:16 Euler's formula with x = pi! The formula can be shown by rearranging the Taylor series for e^x. 4:20 Small detail: Getting hit by the negative sign changes TSC's direction, another allusion to the complex plane! 4:22 e^(i*pi) to e^0 corresponds to the motion along the unit circle on the complex plane. 4:44 The +1/-1 "saber" hit each other to give out "0" sparks. 4:49 -4 saber hits +1 saber to change to -3, etc. 4:53 2+2 crossbow fires out 4 arrows. 4:55 4 arrow hits the division sign, aligning with pi to give e^(i*pi/4), propelling it pi/4 radians round the unit circle. 5:06 TSC propelling himself by multiplying i, rotating pi radians around the unit circle.  5:18 TSC's discovery of the complex plane (finally!) 5:21 The imaginary axis; 5:28 the real axis. 5:33 The unit circle in its barest form. 5:38 2*pi radians in a circle. 5:46 How the radian is defined -- the angle in a unit circle spanning an arc of length 1. 5:58 r*theta -- the formula for the length of an arc with angle theta in a circle with radius r. 6:34 For a unit circle, theta / r is simply the angle. 6:38 Halfway around the circle is exactly pi radians. 6:49 How the sine and cosine functions relate to the anticlockwise rotation around the unit circle -- sin(x) equals the y-coordinate, cos(x) equals to the x-coordinate. 7:09 Rotation of sin(x) allows for visualization of the displacement between sin(x) and cos(x). 7:18 Refer to 4:16  7:28 Changing the exponent by multiples of pi to propel itself in various directions. 7:34 A new form!? The Taylor series of e^x with x=i*pi. Now it's got infinite ammo!? Also like that the ammo leaves the decimal expansion of each of the terms as its ballistic markings. 7:49 The volume of a cylinder with area pi r^2 and height 8. 7:53 An exercise for the reader (haha) 8:03 Refer to 4:20 8:25 cos(x) and sin(x) in terms of e^(ix) 8:33 This part I do not understand, unfortunately... TSC creating a "function" gun f(x) = 9tan(pi*x), so that shooting at e^(i*pi) results in f(e^(i*pi))= f(-1) = 0. (Thanks to @anerdwithaswitch9686 for the explanation -- it was the only interpretation that made sense to me; still cannot explain the arrow though, but this is probably sufficient enough for this haha) 9:03 Refer to 5:06 9:38 The "function" gun, now "evaluating" at infinity, expands the real space (which is a vector space) by increasing one dimension each time, i.e. the span of the real space expands to R^2, R^3, etc. 9:48 log((1-i)/(1+i)) = -i*pi/2, and multiplying by 2i^2 = -2 gives i*pi again. 9:58 Blocking the "infinity" beam by shortening the intervals and taking the limit, not quite the exact definition of the Riemann integral but close enough for this lol  10:17 Translating the circle by 9i, moving it up the imaginary axis 10:36 The "displacement" beam strikes again! Refer to 7:09  11:26 Now you're in the imaginary realm.  12:16 "How do I get out of here?" 12:28 Don't quite get this one... Says "exit" with 't' being just a half-hidden pi (thanks @user-or5yo4gz9r for that) 13:03 n! in the denominator expands to the gamma function, a common extension of the factorial function to non-integers. 13:05 Substitution of the iterator from n to 2n, changing the expression of the summands. The summand is the formula for the volume of the n-dimensional hypersphere with radius 1. (Thanks @brycethurston3569 for the heads-up; you were close in your description!)  13:32 Zeta (most known as part of the Zeta function in Analysis) joins in, along with Phi (the golden ratio) and Delta (commonly used to represent a small quantity in Analysis) 13:46 Love it -- Aleph (most known as part of Aleph-null, representing the smallest infinity) looming in the background.

Okay, let's break down the math journey of the orange stick figure in that cool animation! It's a mix of real math concepts, visual gags, and a journey towards one very famous equation.  Think of it like this: The stick figure is exploring the world of numbers and symbols, sometimes playing with them, sometimes discovering deep connections.  Part 1: Simple Counting and Arithmetic (with some tricks!)  1=1: It starts by showing the basic idea that a number equals itself.  1+1=2: It turns the equals sign into a plus and duplicates the '1' to show simple addition.  Adding More 1s: It continues adding 1s (1+1+1=3, 1+1+1+1=4...). This is just basic counting.  Arithmetic Gags: Soon, the math gets deliberately weird!  It shows things like 1+1+1 = 10 or 2+2+2+2 = 20. This isn't correct math! It's a visual gag where the stick figure manipulates the digits or just makes up results for fun or to show frustration/power.  It eventually gets to 100 through a series of these incorrect or visually manipulated steps.  Simplifying to 100: It then correctly shows 1+99=100.  Subtraction: It correctly shows 100-1=99, 100-1-1=98, and even the clever 100-1-1-98 = 0.  More Gags: It then shows incorrect subtraction like 98-1-1 = -1. Again, visual trickery.  Part 2: Euler's Identity (The Famous Bit)  -1 = e^(iÏ€): This is the first major reveal. The stick figure changes -1 into e^(iÏ€). This is a real and very famous mathematical equation called Euler's Identity. It connects five fundamental mathematical constants:  e (Euler's number, the base of natural logarithms, â‰ˆ 2.718)  i (the imaginary unit, âˆš-1)  Ï€ (Pi, the ratio of a circle's circumference to its diameter, â‰ˆ 3.141)  1 (the multiplicative identity)  0 (the additive identity) The full identity is usually written as e^(iÏ€) + 1 = 0, which means e^(iÏ€) must equal -1.  Abstract Play: The stick figure then plays with the components i, e, and Ï€ in an abstract way, not representing specific math operations.  Part 3: Revisiting Concepts (Powers, Roots, Division)  Multiplication/Division: It shows correct relationships like 12 = 6 x 2 and 3 = 6 / 2.  Division by Zero: It shows 6 / (1-1) which is 6 / 0. Division by zero is undefined in mathematics, and the animation shows this by causing chaos.  Powers: It correctly shows 6Â² = 36, (6+2)Â² = 8Â² = 64, (6-2)Â² = 4Â² = 16, and 4âµ = 1024. It visually represents these large numbers with grids of '1's.  Roots & Exponents: It correctly shows 4Â¹ = 4, 4â° = 1, 4â»Â¹ = 1/4. Then it shows âˆš4 = 2.  Imaginary Unit Again: It shows âˆš(-1) = i, reminding us of the imaginary unit.  Properties of i: Correctly shows i + i = 2i and i * i = -1. It then incorrectly shows i*i*i = -1 (it's actually -i) and i*i*i*i = e^(iÏ€) (it's actually 1, while e^(iÏ€) is -1). This leads back to the incorrect -1 = 1 before resetting.  Part 4: Visualizing Euler's Formula  The Unit Circle: This is the most visual explanation. The stick figure draws a circle on a graph (the complex plane, with real numbers left/right and imaginary numbers up/down). The circle has a radius of 1.  Rotation: It shows a point starting at 1 on the real axis. As it rotates around the circle by an angle (theta, Î¸), its position is given by cos(Î¸) on the real axis and sin(Î¸) on the imaginary axis. So the point is cos(Î¸) + i sin(Î¸).  The Key Angle (Ï€): When the angle is Ï€ radians (180 degrees), the point lands exactly on -1 on the real axis. At this point, cos(Ï€) = -1 and sin(Ï€) = 0.  The Connection: Euler's Formula (a more general version of the Identity) states e^(iÎ¸) = cos(Î¸) + i sin(Î¸).  Putting it Together: So, if you put Ï€ in for the angle Î¸: e^(iÏ€) = cos(Ï€) + i sin(Ï€) = -1 + i(0) = -1. This visually demonstrates why e^(iÏ€) = -1.  Part 5: Advanced Representations (The Crazy Formulas)  Series Expansions: The video briefly shows the infinite series (Taylor series) for e^x, cos(x), and sin(x). These are ways to calculate these functions by adding up an infinite number of terms. It visually shows the terms for e^(iÏ€) adding up and spiraling towards the value -1.  Other Formulas: It flashes many other complex formulas involving integrals, the Gamma function (Î“), the Zeta function (Î¶), logarithms, etc. These are all different, advanced ways mathematicians can express or relate these concepts. You don't need to understand them all; it's showing the depth and interconnectedness of mathematics around Euler's identity.  Conclusion: The Beauty of Math  The stick figure "fights" these complex formulas, gets overwhelmed, but ultimately finds peace with the simple, elegant equation: e^(iÏ€) + 1 = 0. It's often called the most beautiful equation in mathematics because it cleanly links those five fundamental constants. The final "exit" is just wordplay on e^(iÏ€).  In simple terms: The video takes us on a wild ride from basic counting, through some funny math mistakes and visual tricks, introduces advanced ideas like imaginary numbers and powers, and finally arrives at and explains (using the unit circle) the beautiful and fundamental Euler's Identity: e^(iÏ€) = -1.

8:40 Huh, that's not how I would've expected a function blaster to work. (To function, if you will.) After all, a function is a machine where you put in one thing, and the function spits out a thing in response. For example, in the video, we see a function called f. This function takes in a number, takes the tangent of that number, multiplies that by 9, and spits out the result. In symbols, the function f can be defined by the equality f(x) = 9 * tan(x). As an example, we can evaluate f at the value Ï€ / 4 (or Ï„ / 8):  f(Ï€ / 4) = 9 * tan(Ï€ / 4) = 9 * 1 = 9  So it would be cool if the function worked like this: TSC tosses a number in between the parentheses and fires the blaster, causing the function f to "eat" that number and act on it, and the result would be shot out of the other end of the equals sign. TSC could toss in the number Ï€ / 4 and fire, and a 9 would be shot out. In fact, it doesn't even have to be something with a nice result. You could very well toss, say, the number 3 into the function f, and the value f(3) is approximately -1.2829.  Of course, you do still need something to defeat the e^(iÏ€) creatures. In that case, you can just toss Ï€ into the function:  f(Ï€) = 9 * tan(Ï€) = 9 * 0 = 0  Actually, tossing in 0 would work just as well:  f(0) = 9 * tan(0) = 9 * 0 = 0  So you fire out a 0 at each e^(iÏ€), turning it into 0e^(iÏ€). That's just 0, so the e^(iÏ€) would be annihilated. Excellent!
4:16 Note that the equality -e^(iÎ¸) = -cos(Î¸) + i sin(Î¸) does not always hold, but -e^(iÎ¸) = -(cos(Î¸) + i sin(Î¸)) does, per Euler's formula. I believe that's what was meant here, so I would've preferred for parentheses to have been used in that way. In fact, it would've made the expression longer, which might have made the animation more dramatic.

7:35 Wouldn't it make more sense for the lower bound to update to the index AFTER the one that was just used? For comparison, if you have a bucket of balls labeled from 0 to 5, and you throw balls 0, 1, and 2, then the next lowest-numbered ball in the bucket should be 3. Ball number 3 should be the smallest number you see when you look in the bucket, not ball number 2.

Animation vs. Math: Advanced Explanation  3:01 Another way of writing multiplication problems is... Write one of the numbers in parentheses. (Multiplication is the default operation in Algebra, and the multiplication symbol is just implied.) Example 1: 7 Ã— 6 = 7(6) Example 2: a Ã— b = ab (This could only work in unknown variables.) 3:04 Exponentiation â€“â€“ A power that tells us how many times do we have to multiply that number. For example: 6Â² is multiplying 6 two times. 3:09 From 1D space to 2D space. (RÂ¹ â€“> RÂ²) 3:15 From 2D space to 3D space. (RÂ² â€“> RÂ³) 3:17 From 3D space to 4D space. (RÂ³ â€“> Râ´) 3:20 From 4D space to 5D space. (Râ´ â€“> Râµ) 3:24 4^(5 â€“ 1) = 4âµ Ã· 4Â¹, 4^(4 â€“ 1) = 4â´ Ã· 4Â¹ and so on. 3:28 Anything raised to the power of zero is always one, because 4â° = 4^(1 â€“ 1) = 4Â¹ Ã· 4Â¹ = 4 Ã· 4 = 1 3:29 Anything raised to a negative power is 1 over that number raised to a positive power. Example 1: 4^(â€“1) = (1/4) Example 2: 6^(â€“3) = (1/(6Â³)) 3:31 A fraction is equal to the numerator divided by the denominator. 3:36 Anything raised to a whole fraction is equal to the base itself (except zero, because dividing by zero is meaningless). 3:38 Anything raised to a half power (or (1/2)) is equal to the square root of the base. 3:39 Square Roots (or radical sign) â€“â€“ The inverse of nÂ², which a number is a perfect square. Note: Not just square roots, there are cube roots, fourth roots, fifth roots and so on. 3:43 âˆš2 is irrational, which is approximately equal to 1.41. 3:48 âˆš0 = 0 3:49 âˆšâ€“1 does not produce a real number, and mathematicians use the number "i" to represent âˆšâ€“1. 3:56 Complex Numbers â€“â€“ An equation written as "a + bi" where "a" is the real part, and "b" is the imaginary part. 3:59 iÂ² = â€“1 4:01 iÂ³ = â€“i = i(â€“1) = ie^(iÏ€). So e^(iÏ€) emerges back. 4:14 iÂ² Ã— e^(iÏ€) = â€“1 Ã— â€“1 = 1. It's now in the real realm. 4:16 e^(iÏ€) = cos(Ï€) + isin(Ï€) 4:22 e^(iÏ€) copied a "Ï€" and put a minus sign in between them to cause the exponent to have a value of zero, and anything raised to zero is always one. 4:44 Notice that the sword crash each other to produce a sparkle of 0, because â€“1 + 1 = 0. 4:49 Notice that â€“4 sword decreases by one each time when the sword hits the +1 sword. 4:56 e^(iÏ€)'s sword turns into a division symbol to block the 4 then throws it to Ï€ to become (Ï€/4). Therefore rotates it to 45Â°. 5:07 Notice that TSC uses "i" as a jump booster because i = e^(i(Ï€/2)). 5:17 The dot is the origin of both the real and imaginary axis. The origin has a value of 0. 5:36 The unit circle is in its barest form. 5:43 A unit circle's circumference is approximately equal to 6.283 radians. 5:48 Each arc of a unit circle's length is one. 5:58 The Parameter Calculations of a Circle: (a) r â€“â€“ The letter that stands for the word "radius", used to calculate the mass of the circle. (b) theta â€“â€“ The symbol used for controlling and the radius the line inside the circle. (Notice that TSC rotates the line inside theta also refers to the line inside the circle too.) 6:34 By setting "theta" as the numerator and "r" as the denominator will result in a value that's approximately equal to 3.14, which is "Ï€". 6:44 Ï€ = cos(Ï€) + sin(Ï€) 6:49 Notice how the sine and cosine functions to the unit circle (even in graphs). 7:10 By multiplying "i" to sin(Ï€), the sine wave overlaps on the cosine wave whose value is â€“1. 7:18 By adding cos(Ï€) to isin(Ï€), we get â€“1, and is equal to e^(iÏ€), it emerges back again.  That's the Advanced Explanation. If I missed something, type in the reply section below!

7:18 cos(Ï€)+isin(Ï€)=e^i(Ï€)

hey can you make this an actual game like this,        import random  # Constants for grid size GRID_SIZE = 40  # Symbols for the grid EMPTY = '.' PLAYER = '@' RESOURCE = 'R' TOWN = 'T' INPUT_NODE = 'I' INQUIRY_NODE = '?' AI_SYSTEM = 'A'  # Player position player_x, player_y = GRID_SIZE // 2, GRID_SIZE // 2  # Grid layers MAX_GRIDS = 5 grids = [[[EMPTY for _ in range(GRID_SIZE)] for _ in range(GRID_SIZE)] for _ in range(MAX_GRIDS)] current_grid = 0  # Initialize a grid with empty cells def initialize_grid(grid_index):     for y in range(GRID_SIZE):         for x in range(GRID_SIZE):             grids[grid_index][y][x] = EMPTY  # Place random nodes in the grid def place_random_nodes(grid_index, symbol, count):     for _ in range(count):         while True:             x = random.randint(0, GRID_SIZE - 1)             y = random.randint(0, GRID_SIZE - 1)             if grids[grid_index][y][x] == EMPTY:                 grids[grid_index][y][x] = symbol                 break  # Print the current grid def print_grid():     print("\n".join("".join(row) for row in grids[current_grid]))     print("Use WASD to move. Press E to switch grids.")  # Process interactions with special nodes def process_special_node(node):     messages = {         RESOURCE: "You found a resource!",         TOWN: "You entered a town!",         INPUT_NODE: "Input node detected. Awaiting data...",         INQUIRY_NODE: "Inquiry node active. Requesting information...",         AI_SYSTEM: "AI system engaged. Processing..."     }     print(messages.get(node, "Unknown node encountered."))  # Handle user input def handle_input(input_char):     global player_x, player_y, current_grid     grids[current_grid][player_y][player_x] = EMPTY  # Remove player from current position      if input_char == 'w' and player_y > 0:  # Up         player_y -= 1     elif input_char == 's' and player_y < GRID_SIZE - 1:  # Down         player_y += 1     elif input_char == 'a' and player_x > 0:  # Left         player_x -= 1     elif input_char == 'd' and player_x < GRID_SIZE - 1:  # Right         player_x += 1     elif input_char == 'e':  # Switch grids         current_grid = (current_grid + 1) % MAX_GRIDS         print(f"Switched to grid: {current_grid}")      current_node = grids[current_grid][player_y][player_x]     if current_node != EMPTY:         process_special_node(current_node)      grids[current_grid][player_y][player_x] = PLAYER  # Place player back in the grid  # Setup the game def setup():     global player_x, player_y, current_grid     random.seed()      for i in range(MAX_GRIDS):         initialize_grid(i)         place_random_nodes(i, RESOURCE, 10)         place_random_nodes(i, TOWN, 5)         place_random_nodes(i, INPUT_NODE, 3)         place_random_nodes(i, INQUIRY_NODE, 3)         place_random_nodes(i, AI_SYSTEM, 2)      grids[current_grid][player_y][player_x] = PLAYER     print_grid()  # Main loop def main_loop():     setup()     while True:         input_char = input("Enter command (WASD to move, E to switch grids, Q to quit): ").lower()         if input_char == 'q':             print("Exiting game. Goodbye!")             break         handle_input(input_char)         print_grid()  if __name__ == "__main__":     main_loop()

Animation vs. Math: Basic Explanation  0:07 In the beginning of math, 1 is given as the first natural number in our number system, which may explain why natural numbers came first before complicated numbers we use today. 0:13 Equality â€“â€“ A relationship between numbers and their values, even equations. 0:18 Addition â€“â€“ The first of the fundamental arithmetic operations. 0:28 Repeated addition of 1s results in omitting them for multiplication. 0:35 The first appearance of 0 in the ones place, it's just a placeholder for numbers that don't have their value. 0:45 Decomposition â€“â€“ A number which has their expanded form or its equivalent sum inside enclosing with the parentheses symbol in the outside. For example: 2 can be written as (1 + 1). 0:49 Adding numbers that are greater than 1 can also be omitted by just adding 1. 1:10 Simplification â€“â€“ In some math equations, they can (or can't) simplify their equations. For example:  40 + 68 + 35 = 108 + 35                       = 143 1:23 Subtraction â€“â€“ The second of the fundamental arithmetic operations. 1:31 Any number subtracts itself is always 0. 1:33 If 0 subtracts 1 (or more numbers), a negative number is born (â€“1).  Which is the opposite side of the positive numbers. Therefore, the positive, negative and zero became known as "integers". 1:39 This is Euler's Identity: â€“1 = e^(iÏ€) 1:49 ie^(iÏ€) is equal to â€“i and this leads to imaginary realm. 2:12 Subtracting negative numbers gives us even bigger negative numbers. Note: Adding negative numbers gives us even smaller negative numbers. So we can think of subtraction as "negative addition". 2:15 Multiplying two negative numbers gives a positive number. 2:24 Multiplication â€“â€“ The third of the fundamental arithmetic operations. 2:26 If a number on the right side has brackets (or parentheses) results in factors of the product. 2:35 Division â€“â€“ The fourth of the fundamental arithmetic operations. Note: Division symbols can have three types (Ã·, / and :). The Ã· symbol is (usually) used in math equations, the / symbol is used in fractions. For example: 1/2 = 1 Ã· 2, and the : symbol is often used in ratios. For example: a:b = a/b or a Ã· b. 2:36 This is called long division, that means you have to take the divisor's number and subtract the dividend on how many times that will take you to 0. 2:48 Dividing any number by 0 doesn't make any sense, because when we use "n" and divide by 0 will just be n â€“ 0 â€“ 0 â€“ 0 â€“ 0... It will take you forever but the dividend is still the same. And that's why n Ã· 0 is undefined. 2:57 Adding or subtracting zero from a number will not change that number's result. So this is why zero is the additive identity.  And that's the Basic Explanation. If I did something wrong, tell me in the reply section below!

Accident, Accident, At division 2:34 (If we take (6) as 6 books, and we practically separate the 6 books 3 by 3, we find that on subtracting 3 from 6 two times we get pair of books equal to 3, whereas the pair of books should have been of 2.  Conclusion,  The minus rule tells you how many times you have subtracted 3. However, when you look at it practically to see how large one part is, confusion arises. You might think that each part will be of size 3 because you are subtracting 3 each time, but the division answer is 2, because when you divide 6 books into 3 equal parts, each part contains 2 books.   Conclusion: The minus rule is mathematically correct, but it interprets division from the perspective of "times" (how many times subtraction occurs), whereas in the practical world, division is understood from the perspective of the size of each part.   This is why confusion arises when we mix practical division (partitioning) with theoretical repeated subtraction.)

How has it already been a year since this dropped?
No matter how many times I'm watching this video time and time again, I begin looking for simpler explanations on the internet when eiÏ€ appears, and am constantly lost starting from 3:15 and beyond until I search for simpler explanations again.  The effort is there, nothing's wrong with the animation level, but it's 100% my least favourite video and series ever because there is literally no fun in watching and fail to enjoy your usual animations when I am too focused on trying to keep up the pace, pause everytime something doesn't make sense to me, having to grasp the so-called logics out there and so on.  That's the problem with maths and why I always hated them (always loved history and the real knowledge you gain from it is way more useful than just numbers).  Because once someone tries to explain you how maths works in their own way/perspective (as in this video) is literally forcing you to start from scratch and have to understand how maths work but from a different perspective, which makes all the small and hard earned things you bothered to try to remember become outdated and useless, so what's the point.  Like it wasn't difficult enough with the "more common and general" view of maths that you get teached at school, which I can say that I'm not missing at all and don't recall maths being useful to me ever since I began working.

I learned more about math in these 14 minutes than in 12 years of school and 3 years of colli.
My favorite part about this whole animation is how people keep saying "if math lessons were like this, everybody would do math!"  Little do they know, math DOES do this. For example: The computer running the animation as a video known as a phone or computer embodies about 90% of these formulas. Without them, we wouldn't be able to do graphics, we wouldn't be able to do circuits, or any of it.  The computer that RENDERED the animation embodies all of the formulas shown in the video.  The bridge you walk over, the house you live in, everything is made up of math. Math is the language of those who build, either for themselves, or for others. You can't run a country without finances, and how do you calculate those finances? How do you make the computer that calculates those finances, or the software that uses that computer?  Math is boring until it's not. Once it stops being boring, it is incredible. :)

8:24 mitosis
I actually really like the characterization of Euler here! (I think that's what that's called lol dyscalculia go brrrr-)  It seems like they're just evil at first, but once Orange breaks the universe it becomes obvious that they *knew* that was gonna happen and thought that *Orange* knew too. A simple miscommunication where they both thought the *other* was the villain, and made peace when they found out they were wrong.   I also like that Euler seems to speak math as a language, therefore making their previous communication difficulties make more sense. (Shown when Orange tries to explain after his world breaking incident that they need to get home, Euler seeming confused, and then Orange showing them by adding a multiplication symbol to their i symbol, which is how *they* opened the door to what wasn't actually the *real* world, but the *imaginary* one, cuz they're an imaginary equation.)  It ends in what's actually a really heartwarming scene where Euler finally opens the *right* door, and then gets some new math friends! I hope they're having a good time :)

A meganalysis of this: 1: a number representing a single entity Equal: a sign representing the sum of a equation Plus: a positive function symbol representing addition 1+1=2 Double equation: this is when you put two plus or minus. 10: a even number Parentheses: 2=(1+1) 3=(1+2) Minus: a negative function symbol representing a take away in math Negative: a negative function symbol representing the negativity or the lowest of a number e i pi: a mathematical equation equaling 0 Multiplication: 3x3=9 (1+1+1+1+1+1+1+1) 3Ã—(4) = (1+1+1..) Division: 6/2=3 12/6=2 81/9=9 Exponent: 6+2Â²=64 4+4Â²=16 Fraction: Â½=20% Square root: sqrt(4)=2 sqrt(16)=4 i.: -1=n i=1. Radian: also known as rad rad=4.8 maximal rad = 6.2 Pi: symbol representing 3.41 tau: symbol representing t below pi Summation: a symbol representing Î£ a calculus sum.  Function: symbol representing f f(x) f(sin) Integral: the symbol representing the integral of a number so far good Ratio: r=100 Idk i quitğŸ˜Š

0:01 pov: link in the beginning of every zelda game
I love how people dont even know what is the imaginary number and still watch this  Imaginary Number (written as 'i') is equal to the square root of -1 which we considered the second dimension in our Real Number Line, the Real Number line with the Imaginary Number line is known as Cartesian Plane, which is basically a place used to graph equations.  Part 2 - 25 likes: Fun Fact is that |i| is not equal to i, but 1, beacuse if you look at the Cartesian Plane, you see that the distance from 0 to i is 1 unit, so |i|=1, and so |-i| is also equal to 1.  The reason of i being 2root(-1) comes with some other weird facts, such as e^(piÃ—i)=-1, i^5=i^2, etc...  About the Cartesian Plane being used to graph equations, the x-axis is the Real Number Line which is the number we insert in an equation, and the y-axis being the Imaginary Number Line where it's the result of the equation respect to the number inserted.  You know the Reals and the Imaginaries, but there are also Complexs, writen in form a+bÃ—i where a and b are real numbers, ex: 5+2i, this equation can't be compressed more than it is beacuse of mathematical number relation reasons.  I is the second, j is the third and k is the fourth dimension in graphing equations. (More nerdy stuff at 75 likes)

I think it would've been really cool if the giant integral staff were used to actually integrate a function.   Picture this: we have the graph of some functionâ€”say, f(x) = 1 - cos(x). (Why is this graph here? I dunno. Maybe TSC created it out of a love of hills.) The e^(iÏ€) creature positions the integral staff at x = 0 and sweeps the staff toward the right. As they do this, the area under the curve lights up, and this charges up the energy of the staff. This is shown by the staff "filling up" with juice from the bottom up. The top of the juice could even trace out a curve, graphing the amount of juice accumulated up to that point, thus graphing an antiderivative of f by the fundamental theorem of calculus. Then, when the integral staff is full, the e^(iÏ€) creature can use its stored-up energy to fire a giant laser at TSC.

Mathematics is a vast and diverse field, covering a wide range of topics from elementary school to advanced university-level studies. It is generally divided into various branches, each with its own set of concepts and principles. Here's a simplified overview:  ### Elementary School Math: 1. **Arithmetic:** Basic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. 2. **Geometry:** Shapes, sizes, and properties of space. 3. **Fractions and Decimals:** Understanding and manipulating fractions and decimals.  ### Middle School Math: 1. **Pre-Algebra:** Introduction to variables, equations, and basic algebraic concepts. 2. **Algebra:** Solving equations, inequalities, and working with variables. 3. **Geometry:** More advanced concepts involving angles, circles, and three-dimensional shapes. 4. **Statistics and Probability:** Basic concepts of data analysis and probability.  ### High School Math: 1. **Algebra II:** More advanced algebraic concepts, including polynomial functions. 2. **Geometry:** Advanced geometry concepts, including trigonometry. 3. **Pre-Calculus:** Introduction to concepts like limits, functions, and complex numbers. 4. **Calculus:** Differential and integral calculus, studying rates of change and accumulation.  ### University-Level Math: 1. **Calculus:** Advanced topics like multivariable calculus and vector calculus. 2. **Linear Algebra:** Study of vector spaces and linear mappings. 3. **Number Theory:** Properties and relationships of numbers, particularly integers. 4. **Abstract Algebra:** Algebraic structures like groups, rings, and fields. 5. **Real Analysis:** Rigorous study of real-valued sequences and functions. 6. **Complex Analysis:** Study of complex numbers and functions. 7. **Topology:** Properties of space that are preserved under continuous transformations.  ### Specialized Areas: 1. **Differential Equations:** Study of equations involving derivatives. 2. **Probability and Statistics:** Advanced statistical methods and probability distributions. 3. **Combinatorics:** Counting and arranging objects in a systematic way. 4. **Graph Theory:** Study of graphs and networks.  Mathematics is a dynamic field, with ongoing research and new discoveries. Different grades and education levels cover varying aspects of these topics. The key is to build a solid foundation in elementary concepts and gradually explore more advanced areas based on interest and academic progression. **Title: A Journey Through the Evolution of Mathematics Education**  **Introduction:** Mathematics has been an integral part of human civilization, evolving and adapting across various educational stages. From the foundational concepts introduced in preschool and kindergarten to the complex theories explored in college, the history of mathematics education is a testament to human curiosity, intellect, and the pursuit of knowledge.  **Preschool and Kindergarten:** In the early stages of education, mathematics begins with simple yet crucial concepts. Preschool and kindergarten lay the groundwork for mathematical thinking through activities that involve counting, recognizing shapes, and understanding basic patterns. Children engage in playful learning experiences that form the building blocks of numerical awareness.  **Elementary School:** Elementary school introduces students to the fundamental principles of arithmetic, geometry, and basic algebra. From addition and subtraction to multiplication tables and division, students gain fluency in essential operations. Geometry lessons delve into the properties of shapes, and mathematical problem-solving becomes a central focus. The goal is to develop a solid mathematical foundation that students can build upon in subsequent educational stages.  **Middle School:** The middle school years mark the transition to more abstract mathematical thinking. Pre-algebra and algebra courses introduce students to variables, equations, and inequalities. Geometry studies expand to include trigonometry, and statistics and probability become part of the curriculum. Middle school mathematics bridges the gap between concrete concepts and the more theoretical aspects of high school mathematics.  **High School:** High school mathematics takes students on a journey through advanced algebra, calculus, and more specialized branches such as number theory and discrete mathematics. Trigonometry deepens, and pre-calculus prepares students for the study of limits and derivatives in calculus. Courses in statistics and probability provide a practical understanding of data analysis. High school mathematics is designed to cultivate critical thinking and problem-solving skills, preparing students for further academic pursuits.  **University-Level Math:** College-level mathematics offers a rich and diverse landscape. Calculus is explored in depth, and students delve into abstract algebra, linear algebra, real analysis, and complex analysis. Specialized areas like differential equations, topology, and number theory become focal points for those pursuing advanced studies in mathematics. The emphasis shifts towards theoretical understanding and mathematical proof, fostering a deeper appreciation for the intricacies of the subject. **Title: Navigating the High School Odyssey: Academics, Growth, and Beyond**  **Introduction:** High school is a transformative chapter in the journey of every student, characterized by academic challenges, personal growth, and the forging of lifelong connections. It serves as a crucial bridge between the formative years of childhood and the impending responsibilities of adulthood.  **Academic Exploration:** The high school curriculum is a mosaic of subjects designed to broaden students' horizons. Core disciplines such as mathematics, science, literature, and social studies provide a well-rounded education. Specialized courses and electives allow students to explore personal interests, whether in the arts, technology, or languages. This academic diversity lays the foundation for informed career choices and fosters a holistic understanding of the world.  **Extracurricular Pursuits:** Beyond the classroom, high school offers a plethora of extracurricular activities. Clubs, sports teams, and artistic endeavors provide students with avenues for self-expression, leadership development, and teamwork. These activities contribute to a vibrant school culture, shaping students into well-rounded individuals with a multitude of skills and experiences.  **Social Dynamics:** High school is a social crucible where friendships are forged, and personal identities solidify. Peer interactions and group dynamics play a significant role in shaping the high school experience. Through collaborative projects, shared challenges, and communal events, students learn not only about the subjects in their textbooks but also about empathy, communication, and the importance of diverse perspectives.  **Personal Growth and Challenges:** Navigating the challenges of adolescence, high school students undergo a transformative period of personal growth. Academic pressures, extracurricular commitments, and the quest for identity can be both exhilarating and daunting. Learning to manage time, cope with setbacks, and cultivate resilience are essential skills developed during these pivotal years.  **Preparation for the Future:** High school serves as a launchpad for future endeavors. College and career guidance, standardized testing, and exploration of potential professions equip students with the tools needed to make informed decisions about their post-high school paths. The experience of high school not only imparts knowledge but also nurtures the skills and resilience required to thrive in an ever-changing world.  **Conclusion:** In essence, high school is more than just an academic institution; it is a crucible of experiences that shape individuals on intellectual, social, and emotional levels. The academic rigors, extracurricular pursuits, social dynamics, and personal growth together form a rich tapestry of learning. As students embark on the journey beyond high school, they carry with them not only a diploma but also a wealth of memories, skills, and friendships that will resonate throughout their lives. High school is a transformative odyssey, preparing students not only for the challenges of higher education and careers but also for the broader canvas of life itself. **Conclusion:** The history of mathematics education reflects the continuous refinement and expansion of human knowledge. From the early stages of counting in preschool to the abstract realms of university-level mathematics, each educational phase contributes to a comprehensive understanding of mathematical concepts. The journey through math education is not merely a progression of skills but a dynamic exploration that shapes critical thinking, problem-solving abilities, and a lifelong appreciation for the beauty and universality of mathematics.

2 = 2 = 5. 2 + 2 = 5 because 20 - 20 = 25 - 25. Now, take that and turn it into 5x4 - 5x4 = 5x5 - 5x5. Now, turn that into 4(5-5) = 5(5-5). 5-5 = 0. So 4 = 5. Therefore, 2 + 2 = 5.

All the reference I know  0:14  x = x 0:19 Addition 0:36 0 Is An 0 thing (a nothing) 0:45 Additive Decomposition 1:11 (a+b)+c=a+b+c=a+(b+c) 1:24 Subtraction 1:31 a - a = 0 when a isn't x(i^y)*infinity 1:35 Negative Number, getting setN (or setZ+) to setZ 1:40 e^(i*pi) = -1 (Euler's identity) 1:51 with i, e^(i*pi) goes to the setI (or setC idk) 2:04 Simplifaction 2:13 TCS discover that setZ- is as big as setZ+ 2:17 -(-a)=+a 2:25 Multiplication 2:29 ab=ba 2:30 12 has 6 ways to multiply 1*12, 2*6, 3*4, 4*3, 6*2, 12*1 (he forgot to include *1) 2:36 Division 2:42 A way to divide, doesn't quite work when a/b mod 1 != 0 2:49 6/0=+-Infinity 3:01 Parenthesis Multiplication 3:05 Powers 3:09 x^2 is 2D (why does this have an extra +) 3:16 x^3 is 3D and so on 3:29 x^0=1 when x isn't a(i^y)*infinity 3:31 Going into setQ 3:39 Square roots 3:43 Going into setQÌ… 3:50 Going into setI 4:04 -1 = e^(i*pi) 4:07 MONSTER 4:12 TCS hits i*e^(i*pi) with i, making -e^(i*pi) making 1 witch is in setR (Real number) 4:15 Euler's formula 4:23 e^0 is 1 so it will go to the inverse position 4:33 Multiplication is faster than addition 4:45 e^(i*pi) + 1 = 0 (Euler's identity) 4:57 Rotates so e^(i*pi) can't be attacked by TSC 5:08 Rotates so he can 5:36 Complexe circle 5:41 A circle is 2*pi rad 6:24 Rotating Theta is genuis 6:39 Going to Trancendals (is that setT?) 6:42 trig 7:10 *i is 90Â° rotation (in the same way 8*i=infinite) 7:19 Euler's formula reversed 7:35 a sum that after 10 minutes, still have no idea what it is, and why it's -1, it's a *sum* 7:43 losing terms as it shoots 7:46 pi*r=circle 7:50 x*pi*r=cyclinder 8:50 Negates TSC position 8:25 The Euler's formula whan you try to make cosine(setC) or sine(setC) 8:33 f(x) = 9*tan(x) 8:44 f(pi*e^(i*pi)) is 0 9:30 why that? e^(pi*i*infinite) is Undefined (+-1) 9:41 The 4D 10:01 Integral (What the fuk it is) 12:01 TSC needs help 12:19 door 12:29 exit 13:07 Using dimensional sum I guess? 13:23 i * infinite D = -1 13:47 Is that Aleph? Literally so good. The way he meets e^iÏ€ and e^iÏ€ disappears by multiplying itself by i and then he again starts to search about the clue of e^iÏ€ and finds the way of maths.  And the division 6 = 6/2 gives 3 after we do minus 2 three times is implemented in such a good way.  The way he goes from 1=1 to gamma function and others equations pretty much says all maths are connected.  I was personally impressed by the way he showed the power of 4. When we write 4^2 we get 4 rows of 1 and 4 Columns of 1 and that's 16.  Similarly when we add 1 in the power of 4 which already had power 2, we see that we now go to the cubical part (z axis) so there will be extra 1 rows or columns in z axis (Sorry i cannot explain in English words because English is my second language but i know it in paper haha)  Similarly when we add one more 1 then we see that each row and columns have their own rows and columns. This was so good. Thank you for creating it. If i am wrong please correct me in reply. Thank you.

Alan Becker's Animation vs. Math videos are a series of animated works that incorporate mathematical. concepts for entertainment and are designed to help you learn about mathematical topics while having fun.  This series explains mathematical ideas and concepts by incorporating them into characters and stories, including Euler's formula.   Euler's formula is a very important mathematical formula for complex numbers and exponential functions, and it shows a seemingly complex relationship.  Connecting this formula to enemy characters and presenting it as an animated story is an interesting way to introduce mathematical concepts to viewers.   The Animation vs. Math series promotes having fun while learning math and incorporates a variety of mathematical ideas to demonstrate the importance of math.  The appearance of Euler's formula as an enemy character adds an element of exploring the world of mathematics in animation, and may provide viewers with an enjoyable learning experience.

If this was a videogame i would be excited for the first boss (Euler) Edit: The attacks for the base form and the second form (shown in 7:35 and more) would be insane. The third phase would be against an onslaught of duplicates as seen in 8:48. Overall, this has great videogame opportunity. The way the f-model-shooter turns into an absolutely overpowered variant as seen in 9:29 from one of the doubles in its second form is a bit unfair, but thats okay since the 4th phase at 10:01 is incredibly well-written and it is immune to it, forcing you to do actual damage. But on your second playthrough, if you look closely enough, you unlock a one-time use that basically insta-skips the 4th phase. Doing so unlocks a secret 5th phase where you have to carry e and escape from the imaginary realm. I would say that this is a beautiful first boss, but the op weapons you can unlock for this exist, so that bumps it down from 9/10 to 7/10. Still better than those mobile game bosses

When Euler's identity lunges at The Second Coming, he puts a negative sign on himself, effectively teleporting him to the opposite side of the circle. Euler's identity gets mad, so they evolve and start shooting math rockets at The Second Coming again. He sees the point on the side of the radius. The Second Coming then grabs a part of the circle and multiplies it by 4, so he can reach the point. He then grabs it off and strikes it with the "sin hammer". This makes a beam that knocks Euler's identity out of the circle. Euler's identity then devolves and turns into cos(Ï€) + isin(Ï€), which then transforms into eiÏ€+ e-iÏ€/2 + eiÏ€- e-iÏ€/2i, which clones Euler's identity by 4. These Eulerâ€™s identities devolve into cos(Ï€) and then proceeds to multiply into four again, making sixteen of Eulerâ€™s identities. It can be further assumed that these Eulerâ€™s identities did this process many more times to make a massive hoard of them. While this process is happening The Second Coming puts a nine, x(multiplication symbol), and a nine onto the equals making =9x1.

The Stick Guy wanted to go to the illogical world, the world that e^(i*pi) was going through via the door, but he couldn't since he was a positive entity (logical entity). So instead, e^(i*pi) reduced him into his primary structure via the infinite-dimension sphere and then converted it into negative, so he could be a negative entity and go into the illogical world.

the actual math:  0:06 1  0:13 equations  0:18 addition, positive integers  0:34 base ten, O as a place holder  0:44 substitution  1:20 subtraction  1:31 0  1:34 -1, preview of e^(int) = -1  2:10 negative integers  2:16 double negative makes a positive  2:20 multiplication  2:28 factors  2:33 division  2:48 division by 0 error  3:03 powers  3:23 x^1 = x, x^0 = 1  3:30 x^(-1) = 1/x  3:35 fractional exponents = roots  3:42 âˆš2 is irrational  3:48 âˆš(-1) = i  3:54 complex numbers  4:00 e^(int) returns, i*i*i = i*(-1) = i*e^(int)  4:15 Euler's formula: e^(ie) = cose + i*sine  4:54 e^(ie) rotates an angle of e  5:12 complex plane  5:33 unit circle  5:38 full circle = 2Ï€ radians  5:55 circle radii  6:36 Ï€  6:41 trigonometry  7:17 Euler's formula again  7:33 Taylor series of e^(int)  7:44 circle + cylinder  8:22 Euler's formula + complex trigonometry  8:29 sine/cose = tane, function f(x) = 9*tan(Ï€x)  9:57 limits, integrals to handle infinity  13:01 factorial--> gamma function  13:04 n-dimensional spheres  13:31 zeta, phi, delta, aleph

Title: "Sparky: Light of Energy"  Act 1: Opening and Attack  In the city of Stickville lives the stickman Sparky, who has an unusual ability - he can accumulate energy inside his body and release it in the form of powerful light. One day, after successfully demonstrating his ability at a local fair, Sparky becomes the target of attention from other stickmen. The members of the mysterious "Darkness" clan believe that his light may threaten their power.  14 stickmen from the clan attack Sparky, trying to overwhelm him and learn the secret of his ability.  Act 2: Escape and Meet Orion  Sparky barely survives the attack and decides to seek help. He meets an old stickman named Orion, who also has an extraordinary ability - the ability to control energy. Orion takes Sparky under his wing and begins teaching him how to control his power and use it to protect himself and others.  Act 3: Preparation and Return  After intense training, Sparky feels ready to return and take on the Dark Clan. He gathers allies among other stickmen who have also suffered from the criminal activities of this clan.  Act 4: The Final Battle  Led by Sparky, the allies travel to the Dark Clan's secret league compound, where a major battle takes place. Sparky uses his light to destroy barriers and support his team. During the fight, Sparky decides to focus all his energy to create a powerful explosion that scatters the opponents.  Act 5: Charging the Laptop  After defeating the Dark Clan, Sparky feels exhausted from using his ability on the edge. He returns to his workshop table, where his laptop is lying - a key tool in his life. Exhausted but determined, Sparky concentrates the last of his energy to charge his laptop and reconnect with his allies and friends.  Epilogue: New Beginnings  The scene ends with the cityscape of Stickville, where Sparky, reconnected, communicates with his friends via laptop, celebrating the victory over evil and channeling his energy into supporting and developing his home community.  This script explores themes of friendship, self-improvement, and using one's abilities for good.

TSC wakes up in a world that looks...and is all black. And he sees that the number 1 is flying over him. And the 1 comes down and lands in front of TSC.  He clicks on the 1 and it turns into "1=1". Otherwise, what TSC did was to do a giant count to 100.  But he felt alone...until he had the brilliant idea to bring the number 100 to the number 98 and subtract 98 from "98" which gives 0. Then he subtracts 1 from "0" and gets -1. He does it up to -3 and adds a - to the "-3". Making it 3.  He started multiplying and dividing.  But before that, TSC had discovered an "ei" and in front of the "...i", he has the symbol "pi".  He discovered the i. I'LL CONTINUE IN THE NEXT COMMENT (OR EDIT).

For anyone still confused about why Euler's Identity is so powerful, I was too until someone put it like this:  Euler's Identity, when expressed as e^(i*pi) + 1 = 0 is such a powerful equation because it represents the five most important numbers in all of mathematics.

Mesmerising ğŸ¤¯ğŸ¤©
This is so beautiful and joyful and strangely moving. Numbers are so inextricably intertwined with music and art and life, seeing them at play like this is like seeing them finally be able to experience the delights of being alive directly themselves, rather than through their infinitely many arbitrarily large unfoldings that make up the feeling substance of life. At the end when the other weird and beautiful numbers joined Euler's identity and the view panned back to show the big guy was Aleph I found myself crying. It was like they were a loving family, happy to be reunited. I can't explain it but it made me feel connected and hopeful and beloved and it was cathartic. So thank you for this video, and for that feeling.

Hi
Alan have you ever considered using netherite in one of the minecraft animations?
As an Art Major, the furthest I really could get was... basic algebra. Variables and such. I think the main problem is that after a point, it became so difficult for my visually-oriented mind to convert the numerics and symbols on the pages into how the actual functions were meant to work. All my poor instructors kept pointing out that my comprehension was sound, but something about... actually *solving* the equations in my mind never quite clicked. I suppose that's why I took a field as distanced from "pure" mathematics as possible!  ... Perhaps if I had a "field" like this to actually, physically poke and prod at these concepts, maybe I would have been able to grasp a lot more. Watching our little protagonist basically "discover" increasing orders of complexity, eventually going as far as to enter numeric dimensions, was a really fascinating way of translating all of this emergent mathematics into a classic Flashy Fight Scene.   It's always cool to see people translate concepts like this into something visual enough to construct a nice narrative! Well done on you and everyone else for putting this all together. It certainly was a wonderful introduction to the rest of your amazing work!

Theory on why Euler's Number (EN) attacked TSC: My theory is that every number has a hunger. The more you summoned the less hungry you are. So, EN wasn't summonning that much (not much as one or two, anyway) so he felt a great hunger. That's why he kinda growled when he first meet TSC. Even though he is hungry, he runs away because he doesnt want to hurt TSC. So, when TSC wants to talk to EN, he fights, to not to kill or hurt TSC, but to protect him. I can prove this in 8:31 . If you look closely, you can see three EN clons actually helping TSC by growing the circle with the help of that angle symbol thingy. At the end, even though EN is hungry, he sees that TSC needs help and overcomes his hunger to help him out. That's why at the end other symbols that aren't summoned much congrats him, because he overcame his hunger. That's why I think TSC was a test for EN, because he is younger, (he is the smallest amongst them) he couldn't control his hunger but with this "test" he has proven that he can control his hunger. So yeah, TSC was a test, because he would come across EN eventually, for EN equals -1 and -1 isnt something hard to obtain. That's my theory, anyway.

ok, ok. this is a masterpiece; there is no doubt about that. BUT, or because of that, I came up with the undeniable proof that (tau) is better in every way possible to (pi). Hear me out: you could have introduced your antagonist (e^i(pi)) a lot earlier.   After the protagonist (TSC) touches 1 and you show 1 = 1,  you could have shown 1 = e^i(tau).  This would have created an even better cinematographic pacing. This would have hinted towards the interconnectivity of all things earlier. Yes, this would have been too big of a jump, but your antagonist, in this case e^i(tau), could have just escaped, like before.  q.e.d.

What gender are they?
Watching this video from the e's point of view makes it much more understandable. At the beginning, the e just wants to be left alone to the annoyance of TSC. However, the e only turns hostile after TSC pins it to the ground, provoking a counter attack and keeps running away. At this point the e becomes geniunely scared of TSC, turns into the sigma cannon and attacks TSC to keep him away from itself. After the sin cannon by TSC, the e becomes increasingly desperate and makes copies of itself to eliminate this threat to it's survival. (Some of the copies do help TSC though. Interesting how that works.) At the end, the e realises that TSC is not a threat but rather a friend. The e was really fighting for it's survival the entire time. An absolute Masterpiece though EDIT: The e really looks happy and relieved at the end with his friends!

I wish schools and teachers left behind the old ways of "we are just quality control and you are defective, here, have a C or a 6 or 60" or whatever you have in your country.

tip 1  Ultimate Chocolate Chip Cookies turn out best when baked one sheet at a time on middle oven rack.  tip 2  The best cookie sheets are shiny aluminum with a smooth surface and no sides. These cookie sheets reflect heat, which helps cookies to bake evenly and brown properly. Rimmed baking sheets will not provide the same results in cookie baking.  tip 3  For best results, measure ingredients accurately using the right measuring equipment for the ingredient being measured. Make sure to add ingredients in the order they are called for.  tip 4  The best way to measure flour for this Ultimate Chocolate Chip Cookies recipe is to first stir the flour a bit before spooning into the measuring cup. Fill until heaping and then sweep the excess off the top with the flat edge of a butter knife.  tip 5  Line flat cookie sheets with parchment paper for easy cleanup. Make sure to give the dropped dough plenty of air space so that the cookies wonâ€™t bump into each other as they spread.  tip 6  Baking science determines what makes a soft, chewy cookie versus a crisp, crunchy cookie. Factors that make a difference include the ratio and type of sugars used, the amount of butter or shortening used, and how much flour is stirred in.  tip 7  Use a 1-inch meat baller (or cookie/ice cream scoop) to make Ultimate Chocolate Chip Cookies that are uniform in shape and size.  tip 8  Want to make jumbo-size Ultimate Chocolate Chip Cookies? Use a measuring cup or cookie/ice cream scoop to scoop out cookie dough, dropping each scoop 3 inches apart. Bake until edges of cookies are set (centers will be soft).  tip 9  This Ultimate Chocolate Chip Cookies recipe can be customized with endless flavor combinations. Just replace the chocolate chips and nuts with the same amount of the new ingredients you want to add. is this part of  math is powerful  for learn  if we're considering the Taylor series expansions for sin(x) and cos(x) around x = 0, they are as follows:  sin(x) = x - xÂ³/3! + xâµ/5! - xâ·/7! + ... cos(x) = 1 - xÂ²/2! + xâ´/4! - xâ¶/6! + ...  If we replace x with (x + Ï€) in these expansions, we'd have to evaluate the series at (x + Ï€) instead. It's also noteworthy that sin(x + Ï€) = -sin(x) and cos(x + Ï€) = -cos(x), which are simpler ways of representing these shifts without computing the entire series.  that really hard to write and seen it

People who don't like math (many people) are afraid of the calculation and complicated formulas that come along with it, but really haven't discovered that beautiful side of it. this is what I am thinging about on my math exam:
I see a great effort in the journey of making Animation, just like all the artists, I believe this video conveys a deep, profound, elegant, pure, and philosophical approach to demonstrate the relationship between the truth within the math, the role of humans, and the way of studying about math. The narrative is simple to understand, whereas, once you think about each interaction that characters made with the symbols, there are a lot of stories to tell behind the history of math, and it takes great effort in understanding all of them. The way all the complex idea of history was condensed into one video was insanely cool. I am totally shocked by this video, equal to or beyond the other great videos I watched from Vsauce or 3B1B.

How ancient Sumerians was building math:
Absolutely incredible! The animation and motion graphics in this video are truly insanely creative and satisfying If only math was taught this well everywhere
This genuinely is a fantastic application of entertainment and educational. The way these mathematic concepts are visualized are FANTASTIC!
THE MATH LORE  0:07 The simplest way to start -- 1 is given axiomatically as the first natural number (though in some Analysis texts, they state first that 0 is a natural number) 0:13 Equality -- First relationship between two objects you learn in a math class. 0:19 Addition -- First of the four fundamental arithmetic operations. 0:27 Repeated addition of 1s, which is how we define the rest of the naturals in set theory; also a foreshadowing for multiplication. 0:49 Addition with numbers other than 1, which can be defined using what we know with adding 1s. (proof omitted) 1:23 Subtraction -- Second of the four arithmetic operations. 1:34 Our first negative number! Which can also be expressed as e^(i*pi), a result of extending the domain of the Taylor series for e^x (\sum x^n/n!) to the complex numbers. 1:49 e^(i*pi) multiplying itself by i, which opens a door to the... imaginary realm? Also alludes to the fact that Orange is actually in the real realm. How can Orange get to the quantity again now?  2:12 Repeated subtraction of (-1)s, similar to what was done with the naturals. 2:16 Negative times a negative gives positive. 2:24 Multiplication, and an interpretation of it by repeated addition or any operation. 2:27 Commutative property of multiplication, and the factors of 12. 2:35 Division, the final arithmetic operation; also very nice to show that - and / are as related to each other as + and x! 2:37 Division as counting the number of repeated subtractions to zero. 2:49 Division by zero and why it doesn't make sense. Surprised that Orange didn't create a black hole out of that.  3:04 Exponentiation as repeated multiplication. 3:15 How higher exponents corresponds to geometric dimension. 3:29 Anything non-zero to the zeroth power is 1. 3:31 Negative exponents! And how it relates to fractions and division. 3:37 Fractional exponents and square roots! We're getting closer now... 3:43 Decimal expansion of irrational numbers (like sqrt(2)) is irregular. (I avoid saying "infinite" since technically every real number has an infinite decimal expansion...) 3:49 sqrt(-1) gives the imaginary number i, which is first defined by the property i^2 = -1. 3:57 Adding and multiplying complex numbers works according to what we know. 4:00 i^3 is -i, which of course gives us i*e^(i*pi)!  4:14 Refer to 3:49 4:16 Euler's formula with x = pi! The formula can be shown by rearranging the Taylor series for e^x. 4:20 Small detail: Getting hit by the negative sign changes Orange's direction, another allusion to the complex plane! 4:22 e^(i*pi) to e^0 corresponds to the motion along the unit circle on the complex plane. 4:44 The +1/-1 "saber" hit each other to give out "0" sparks. 4:49 -4 saber hits +1 saber to change to -3, etc. 4:53 2+2 crossbow fires out 4 arrows. 4:55 4 arrow hits the division sign, aligning with pi to give e^(i*pi/4), propelling it pi/4 radians round the unit circle. 5:06 Orange propelling himself by multiplying i, rotating pi radians around the unit circle.  5:18 Orange's discovery of the complex plane (finally!) 5:21 The imaginary axis; 5:28 the real axis. 5:33 The unit circle in its barest form. 5:38 2*pi radians in a circle. 5:46 How the radian is defined -- the angle in a unit circle spanning an arc of length 1. 5:58 r*theta -- the formula for the length of an arc with angle theta in a circle with radius r. 6:34 For a unit circle, theta / r is simply the angle. 6:38 Halfway around the circle is exactly pi radians. 6:49 How the sine and cosine functions relate to the rotation around the unit circle -- sin(x) equals the y-coordinate, cos(x) equals to the x-coordinate. 7:09 Rotation of i to sin(x) allows for visualization of the displacement between sin(x) and cos(x). 7:18 Refer to 4:16  7:28 Changing the exponent by multiples of pi to propel itself in various directions. 7:34 A new form!? The Taylor series of e^x with x=i*pi. Now it's got infinite ammo!? Also like that the ammo leaves the decimal expansion of each of the terms as its ballistic markings. 7:49 The volume of a cylinder with area pi r^2 and height 8. 7:53 An exercise for the reader (haha) 8:03 Refer to 4:20 8:25 cos(x) and sin(x) in terms of e^(ix) 8:33 This part I do not understand, unfortunately... 9:03 Refer to 5:06 9:38 The "infinity" gun expands the real space (which is a vector space) by increasing one dimension each time, i.e. the span of the real space expands to R^2, R^3, etc. 9:48 log((1-i)/(1+i)) = -i*pi/2, and multiplying by 2i^2 = -2 gives i*pi again. 9:58 Blocking the "infinity" beam by shortening the intervals and taking the limit, not quite the exact definition of the Riemann integral but close enough for this lol  10:17 Translating the circle by 9i, moving it up the imaginary axis 10:36 The "displacement" beam strikes again! Refer to 7:09  11:26 Now you're in the imaginary realm.  12:16 "How do I get out of here?" 12:28 Don't quite get this one... Says "exit" with 't' being just a half-hidden pi (thanks @user-or5yo4gz9r for that) 13:03 n! in the denominator expands to the gamma function, a common extension of the factorial function to non-integers. 13:05 Substitution of the iterator from n to 2n, changing the expression of the summands. The summand is the formula for the volume of the n-dimensional hypersphere with radius 1. (Thanks @brycethurston3569 for the heads-up; you were close in your description!)  13:32 Zeta (most known as part of the Zeta function in Analysis) joins in, along with Phi (the golden ratio) and Delta (commonly used to represent a small quantity in Analysis) 13:46 Love it -- Aleph (most known as part of Aleph-null, representing the smallest infinity) looming in the background

Copy pasting a comment from an YouTube user named @wittyboy1009 with all the Math topics shown in the movie.  0:07 introduction to numbers 0:11 equations 0:20 addition 1:24 subtraction 1:34 negative numbers 1:40 e^i*pi = -1, euler's identity 2:16 two negatives cancellation 2:24 multiplication 2:29 the commutative property 2:29 equivalent multiplications 2:35 division 2:37 second division symbol 2:49 division by zero is indeterminate 3:05 Indices/Powers 3:39 One of the laws of indices. Radicals introcuced. 3:43 Irrational Number 3:50 Imaginary numbers 3:59 i^2 = -1 4:01 1^3 = -i = i * -1 = ie^-i*pi 4:02 one of euler's formulas, it equals -1 5:18 Introduction to the complex plane 5:36 Every point with a distance of one from the origin on the complex plane 5:40 radians, a unit of measurement for angles in the complex plane 6:39 circumference / diameter = pi 6:49 sine wave 6:56 cosine wave 7:02 sin^2(Î¸) + cos^2(Î¸) = 1 7:19 again, euler's formula 7:35 another one of euler's identities 8:25 it just simplifies to 1 + 1/i 8:32 sin (Î¸) / cos (Î¸) = tan (Î¸) 9:29 infinity. 9:59 limit as x goes to infinity 10:00 reduced to an integral 11:27 the imaginary world 13:04 Gamma(x) = (x-1)! 13:36 zeta, delta and phi 13:46 aleph

For all those wondering the e represents Eulers number, with the whole thing representing Eulers identity which showed that e to the power of i (the unit representing imaginary numbers) multiplied by pi. At the end, the other four characters shown were Zeta (Î¶), Phi (Ï†), Delta (ğ›¿), and Aleph (the massive figure shown at the end, representing the cardinality (size) of infinite sets)

This is a certified banger of a video.  It presents maths to all ages in the most cool, accessible and simplistic ways possible, showing hard and abstract concepts in understandable ways that can only be done in animation.   It rewards those that have spent their lives on the subject. The pride in knowing every equation, every proof and every little Easter egg, is validation and recognition for their efforts in learning and expanding on the vast sea of knowledge that is  mathematics.  It helps people that are in the middle of learning math. It motivates the demotivated by displaying how cool maths can be, and guides those that are struggling by presenting concepts in fun and simple ways.  Most importantly however, it inspires and draws people to math. Those that never tried math will be inspired and those that dislike math may give it a second chance after seeing how cool maths can be.  This is one of the best, if not the best, math videos of time.

0:07 The Start. 0:14 Equal Sign --- Usage: Shows What A Value Is "Equal" To --- Example: 1 = 1 0:19 Plus Sign / Addition --- Usage: To "Add" A Value To Another Value --- Example: 1 + 1 = 2 0:34 Numbers Can Have More Than 1 Digit --- Example: 10 1:10 Making Shortage On Equations --- Example: 20 + 20 + 20 = 20 + 40 1:18 A Number Always Equals A Value Of Itself --- Example: 100 = 100 1:20 Minus Sign / Subtraction --- Usage: To "Remove" A Value From Another Value --- Example: 100 - 1 = 99 1:31 If A Number Is Being Subtracted With Its Value It Always Equals 0 --- Example 100 - 1 - 1 - 98 = 0 1:34 Negative Numbers Discovered 1:39 (Euler's Number) e ^ iÏ€ = -1 1:49 ie ^ iÏ€ Belongs In A Place Called The "Imaginary World" Due To It Being A "Imaginary Number" 2:15 Adding 2 Negative Signs Makes It Positive --- Example: -1 - 1 - 1 = - -3 = 1 + 1 + 1 = 3 2:24 Times Sign / Multiplication --- Usage: Takes A Value And "Adds" The Value An Amount Of "Times" --- Example: ( 1 + 1 + 1 ) + ( 1 + 1 + 1 ) + ( 1 + 1 + 1 ) = 3 * 3 2:35 Divide Sign / Division --- Usage: Takes A Value And Finds How Many Of Another Value Is In That Value --- Example 3 = 6 / 2 3:04 Exponent Sign / To The Power Of --- Usage: Takes A Value And "Multiplies" The Value By Itself An Amount Of "Times" --- Example: 6 ^ 2 = 36 3:31 If A Value Is To The Power Of -1 It Will Equal 1/(Value) --- Example: 4 ^ -1 = 1/4 3:39 Square Root --- Usage: Reverse "(Value ^ 2)" --- Example: âˆš 4 = 2 3:50 (Imaginary Number) i Appears In âˆš -(Any Number) 4:00 i ^ 3 = ie ^ iÏ€ 4:15 e ^ iÏ€ = cos ( Ï€ ) + i sin ( Ï€ ) 4:19 Negitive Direction ( -90 dir -->  ( - -90 dir ) = ( 90 dir ) ) 4:21 e ^ (iÏ€ - Ï€) = e ^ 0 ( Turn 180 deg ) 4:33 Multiplying Legs Speed 4:56 e ^ ( i ( Ï€ / 4 ) ) (45 deg counterclockwise) 5:16 Unit Line 5:36 Unit Circle ( Î¸ ) 5:52 (Radius) r ( Size Of Î¸ ) --- r = 1 6:35 ( dir = 90 ) Î¸/r=0 6:39 ( dir = -90 ) Î¸/r=Ï€ 6:44 Ï€ = cos ( Ï€ ) sin ( Ï€ ) 6:49 sin ( Ï€ ) + Î¸r = ( sin tÏ€ 90 dir ) 6:55 cos ( Ï€ ) + Î¸r = ( cos tÏ€ 0 dir ) 7:09 i sin ( Ï€ ) + Î¸r = ( sin tÏ€ 0 dir) 7:35 e ^ x --- x = i( Ï€ ) 7:49 8Ï€r ^ 2 = 8r Cylinder 7:54 r - Is this part of season 4
I derived immense enjoyment from witnessing the mesmerizing animation depicting the enthralling encounter between mathematical concepts engaged in fierce combat. The seamless integration of mathematical principles with the dynamic visual medium creates a captivating spectacle, where the abstract realm of numbers and equations is brought to life in a visually stimulating manner. This unique fusion of art and mathematics allows for a fresh and engaging perspective on these traditionally abstract concepts. Through the medium of animation, the intricacies of mathematical operations and the elegance of mathematical relationships are personified, transforming them into formidable adversaries engaged in an epic clash. Such an imaginative portrayal instills a sense of excitement and wonder, highlighting the inherent beauty and dynamism that lie within the realm of mathematics.

Letâ€™s see: 0:14 the number 1, also equalities 0:27 addition  1:32  subtraction 1:42 negative numbers  1:48 Eulerâ€™s identity, in trig, a number in the form e^ix can be represented as a point on the unit circle (circle with radius one whose center is the origin on the complex plane), the x is the angle in radiants at which the point is located, since pi radiants is 180 degrees, the identity equals -1.  2:25 double negative makes positive  2:32 multiplication  2:43 division 2:57 dont divide by 0, please 3:14 positive exponents 3:38 negative exponents 3:44 rational exponents/ radicals 3:59 Imaginary numbers, normally you canâ€™t take the principal square root of a negative number, so some old smart guy made imaginary numbers (i) where I squared is -1. 4:22 the euler identity tried to escape by multiplying itself by i, but the i that was thrown made the i into a -1, which is why when the eulers identity went through the wall, it didnt dissaper 4:25 trigonometry representation on eulers identity, sometimes written as cis (cos + isin) for anyone studying trigonometry, you know the beauty of working with complex numbers in trig form 4:31 pi radiants is 180 degrees thus the half circle 4:28 the - flipped orange guy (TSC)  5:01 the bow is made up of two twos and a multiplication sign, so it shoots out 4s 5:04 pi/4 rad is 45 degrees so the circle isnâ€™t complete 5:26 complex plane( reals on x axis imaginary on y) 5:43 unit circle  5:50 2pi rad in circle 5:57 definition of radiant 6:12 r is radius, theta is angle 6:46 pi :) 6:52 cos and sin, and how their graphs are drawn using the unit circle. You can see on the graph that the graph cycle every 2pi, this is the period of the graph. 7:17 i rotates the sin wave 90 degrees 7:28 same eulers identity 7:43 Taylor series (complicated stuff) if im wrong plz correct me, also shoots out the answer. 7:53 circle and cylinder  8:11 TSC uses the - to go to the opposite side 8:33 complex definitions of sin and cos (rest in replyâ€™s cause itâ€™s getting too long)
